name: Tawang Monastery
header_quote: A golden citadel floating above the clouds.

story.overview: Founded by Merag Lama Lodre Gyatso, this fortified complex is the spiritual heart of the Monpa people. It houses a Parkhang (library) with ancient manuscripts and a 28-foot Golden Buddha.
story.culturalSignificance: The second largest monastery in the world; center of the Gelugpa school.
story.localBelief: Site chosen by a celestial horse (Ta-Wang).

name: Sela Pass
header_quote: The frozen gateway to the hidden land.

story.overview: A critical waypoint featuring the Sela Lake, often frozen in winter. It serves as a botanical boundary for rhododendrons.
story.culturalSignificance: Site of conflict during the 1962 war.
story.localBelief: Named after Sela, a local girl who aided a soldier.

name: Sangetsar Lake
header_quote: Where dead trees stand guard over silent waters.

story.overview: Formed by a tectonic earthquake in 1971. Characterized by eerie, upright trunks of dead trees emerging from the water.
story.culturalSignificance: Popularized by the Bollywood movie Koyla.

name: Nuranang Falls
header_quote: A thunderous cascade in the Jang valley.

story.overview: Unlike seasonal falls, this is perennial and feeds a hydel plant. Also known as Jang Falls.
story.culturalSignificance: Site of song shooting for movie Koyla.

how_to_get_there: Stop on the way to Tawang.

story.overview: A vital center for the Gelugpa school. Offers panoramic views of Kangto and Gorichen peaks.
story.culturalSignificance: Contrast to the older Tawang monastery architecture.

story.overview: Biodiversity hotspot where the Bugun Liocichla bird was discovered. Spans tropical to temperate zones.
story.culturalSignificance: Named after the Indian Army's Red Eagle Division.

story.overview: Known for its hornbill nest adoption program. Connects to Nameri National Park in Assam.
Built by the Chutiya Kingdom. The city Itanagar is named after this 'Fort of Bricks'.
story.culturalSignificance: Challenges the notion that the region lacked stone architecture.

name: Ziro Valley
header_quote: Golden paddy fields and tattooed faces.

story.overview: Home to the Apatani tribe, famous for paddy-cum-fish cultivation and facial tattoos.

name: Namdapha National Park
header_quote: Where the four big cats roam.

story.overview: India's easternmost tiger reserve. Home to Tiger, Leopard, Snow Leopard, and Clouded Leopard.

name: Parashuram Kund
header_quote: Washing away the sins in the Lohit.

story.overview: Thousands take a holy dip here during Makar Sankranti. Situated on the lower reaches of the Lohit River.
story.culturalSignificance: Linked to the legend of Parashuram washing his axe.

name: Mechuka Valley
header_quote: A hidden paradise of horses and snow.

story.overview: A breathtaking valley with the 400-year-old Samten Yongcha monastery. Offers a blend of nature and spirituality.
story.culturalSignificance: Historically part of the Tibetan trade route.

name: Dong Valley
header_quote: Catch the first ray of light.

story.overview: The location that receives the first sunlight in India. Requires a trek to the peak.

name: Kaziranga National Park
header_quote: The land of the unicorn rhino.

story.overview: Hosts two-thirds of the world's great one-horned rhinoceroses. Vast elephant grass and marshland.
Hub of Neo-Vaishnavite culture housing numerous Satras. Famous for mask-making and pottery.
story.culturalSignificance: Cradle of Satriya dance and music.

name: Kamakhya Temple
header_quote: Where the mother goddess is worshipped.

story.overview: Located on Nilachal Hill. Center of the Kulachara Tantra Marga. Hosts the Ambubachi Mela.
story.culturalSignificance: Celebrates the menstruation of the goddess.

story.overview: Two-storied royal sports pavilion built by Ahom kings. Used for buffalo fights and other sports.
Holds the highest density of One-horned Rhinos in the world. Close to Guwahati.
Bounded by Brahmaputra and Lohit rivers. Famous for feral horses and river dolphins.
Centerpiece of Haflong town. Known for scenic beauty and cool climate.
Famous for Muga and Pat silk weaving. Almost every household has a loom.
Famous for Phumdis (floating biomass). Hosts Keibul Lamjao, the only floating national park.
Houses temples, colonial ruins, and the Govindajee temple. Historic seat of power.
A centuries-old market run exclusively by women. Hub for handlooms and produce.
Only place in the world where Lilium mackliniae grows. Blooms in May-June.

how_to_get_there: Drive from Imphal to Ukhrul, then trek.

story.overview: Marks the site of the 1891 Anglo-Manipuri war. Features the Paona Brajabashi statue.

name: Nohkalikai Falls
header_quote: A tragic leap into emerald waters.

story.overview: Plunges 340 meters into a green pool. Rain-fed spectacular sight.
story.culturalSignificance: Named after Likai, a woman who jumped off the cliff.

story.overview: Grown from Ficus elastica roots by Khasi people. The Double Decker at Nongriat is famous.
Famous for emerald clear waters. Borders Bangladesh.
UNESCO site. Home to Red Panda and wild oranges.
Large man-made reservoir. Popular for water sports and scenic beauty.
Prominent hill offering views of valleys. Features a model Mizo heritage village.
750 feet high two-tiered waterfall. Surrounded by dense bamboo forests.
Home to the Goral and diverse orchids. Highest peak (2157m).
story.culturalSignificance: Abode of the gods in Mizo folklore.

story.overview: Geographically in Myanmar but culturally Mizo. Central to folklore about the afterlife.
story.culturalSignificance: Souls pass through here on way to Pialral.

story.overview: Heritage complex showcasing architecture of 16 Naga tribes. Venue of Hornbill Festival.
Rolling green hills and seasonal flowers. Famous for Dzukou Lily.
story.culturalSignificance: Shared heritage of Angami and Mao tribes.

name: Kohima War Cemetery
header_quote: When you go home, tell them of us.

story.overview: On Garrison Hill, site of the tennis court battle. Maintained by CWGC.
story.culturalSignificance: Turning point of WWII in the East.

story.overview: Historic Angami village known for resisting British and now for conservation (Tragopan sanctuary).

name: Longwa Village
header_quote: Bedroom in India, kitchen in Myanmar.

story.overview: The Angh's (Chief's) house sits on the border. Villagers move freely between countries.
Former royal palace of Manikya dynasty, now a state museum. Built in 1901.
Summer palace built in the middle of Rudrasagar Lake. Blend of Hindu and Islamic architecture.
story.culturalSignificance: Only water palace in NE India.

story.overview: Massive bas-relief sculptures of Shiva carved into the hill. Dates to 7th-9th century.
Ancient temple dedicated to Goddess Kali. Shaped like a tortoise (Kurma Peeth).
High altitude lake at 12,400 ft. Remains frozen in winter.
story.localBelief: Lamas predict future by water color.

story.overview: Historic trade route at 14,140 ft. Tourists can shake hands with Chinese soldiers across the fence.
Largest monastery in Sikkim. Seat of the Black Hat sect (Kagyu).
story.culturalSignificance: Golden Stupa contains relics of 16th Karmapa.

name: Pelling
header_quote: Closest view of the sleeping Buddha.

story.overview: Hill station offering the closest view of Mt Kanchenjunga. Base for Pemayangtse Monastery.
One of the highest lakes in the world. Guru Padmasambhava touched it, so part of it never freezes.
Alpine valley with river and hot springs. Blooms with rhododendrons in spring.
Complex featuring replicas of four Dhams and a giant Shiva statue.
